abstracts.cdata!:
The PPAR rates project outcome as
            moderately unsatisfactory rather than satisfactory because
            although reasonable success was achieved in meeting several
            of the quantitative targets, several fundamental issues
            crucial to efficient fuelwood supply management were not
            thoroughly addressed, and there were significant
            shortcomings on the demand side. Project sustainability is
            non-evaluable at this stage. Bank performance is rated
            unsatisfactory because project design had significant
            shortcomings despite the long preparation period, and
            supervision was also wanting on several fronts. Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory. This project offeres
            several lessons for similar interventions in Mali and
            elsewhere, among them: 1) The importance of budgeting
            adequate time and resources in a follow-on project to
            consolidate the achievements and overcome the challenges of
            the predecessor project cannot be overemphasized. 2) It is
            important that appropriate incentives be provided to Bank
            and Borrower project teams so that they design performance
            indicators that monitor outcomes. Only then can effective
            results be achieved. 3) Given the poverty alleviation
            mandate of the Bank, in a Program of Targeted Intervention
            it is important that development objectives be framed partly
            in terms of poverty reduction. This should be done in a way
            that is monitorable and should be backed up in a design by a
            monitoring and evaluation system capable of measuring
            poverty impact.
